articles.content: Snowiest.app is your new model comparison tool to predict the snowfall for your next trip. Photo Snowiest.app We’ve all been there: staring at three different weather apps trying to decipher if there will be fresh snow for your day at the resort. The issue isn’t a lack of options or data; it’s that predicting weather patterns and snowfall in the mountains is incredibly difficult, and with so many outlooks available, who can you trust? Enter Snowiest.app , a free, donation-based weather aggregator website that is putting the raw data directly into the hands of skiers and riders. A breakdown of the resorts expecting to receive the most snowfall in the next 5 days. Photo Snowiest.app Snowiest isn’t a forecaster—it’s a model comparison tool. It helps you see agreement and uncertainty across multiple model outputs in one place . Designed for transparency, it puts the raw numbers front and center. articles.title: Palisades Tahoe Forecasting 32-40 Inches of Snow In The Coming Week
articles.description: Palisades Tahoe is gearing up for a significant multi-day storm that could deliver up to 40 inches of snow by Wednesday morning.
articles.content: Palisades Tahoe meteorologist Bryan Allegretto is looking at a slow-moving weather system will bring snow to the Sierra Nevada starting Monday, with snowfall rates increasing through the afternoon and evening hours. Storm Timeline The action begins Monday as southerly flow pushes precipitation into the region. A colder storm drops in from the northwest on Tuesday, increasing snowfall rates with westerly flow and frigid temperatures. Snow levels will drop near the base Monday morning, falling to around 5,000 feet by Monday evening and near 4,000 feet Monday night into Tuesday. By early Wednesday morning, the forecast is looking toward some pretty impressive 2-day storm totals, including 22-30 inches at the base, 28-35 inches mid-mountain, and 32-40 inches at the upper mountain. Palisades Tahoe live camera. Credit: Palisades Tahoe Ridgetop winds will be strongest Monday afternoon through Tuesday, with gusts reaching 80+ mph. articles.title: Underrated Alberta Ski Resort Opens New Chairlift & Terrain Expansion
articles.description: The Alberta ski resort marked a major milestone in its 60th anniversary season with the opening of a new terrain expansion.
articles.content: Alberta — Yesterday was a historic day for one of the up-and-coming ski resorts in North America. Yesterday, Castle Mountain Resort opened up the Stagecoach Express chairlift for the first time. Previously only accessible to cat skiing guests, this new terrain pod is now serviced by a detachable high-speed quad chairlift. The opening was marked by a ceremonial ribbon-cutting. “The introduction of our first high-speed lift is a major milestone for Castle and a meaningful step forward for the resort,” said Cole Fawcett, Sales & Marketing Manager at Castle. “This expansion opens up some incredible new terrain, dramatically improving the amount of skiable acreage and the diversity of trails, and allows more guests to experience more of what makes this place so special. articles.content: Mt. Shasta Ski Park, California, has temporarily closed amid low snowpack and heavy rain. | Photo: Webcam image from the base of Mt. Shasta Ski Park this morning, Tuesday, February 10, 2026. Mt. Shasta Ski Park , California, has temporarily closed amid low snowpack and heavy rain, the resort announced on social media yesterday . It hopes incoming storms allow a quick return. The independent ski area , located in McCloud, announced the closure as unseasonably warm and dry conditions have left the resort with only 79 inches of snow this season. The resort opened on December 27 and has received no new snow in February. General Manager Brendan Hickey addressed the closure in a video message, standing at the base of muddy slopes. He confirmed that incoming weather systems are forecast to bring snow to the region. The ski park hopes to reopen by Friday, February 13, following big snow from the forecasted storm system. articles.title: PlanetSKI Hits the Mountains & Valleys in Switzerland
articles.description: Our roving reporter Nick Dalton spends several days on the ski slopes of Grindelwald, then decamps for life and adventure in the valley. A winter experience with a difference. NEW The post PlanetSKI Hits the Mountains & Valleys in Switzerland appeared first on PlanetSKI .
articles.content: It was, as they say, a game of two halves So often PlanetSKI is told that there’s much more to winter in the mountains, and so often we’re not fully convinced. Other pastimes when we could be on the slopes? Er, no thanks. But Switzerland’s Jungfrau region and its elegant lakeside town of Interlaken has made us think again. THE SKIING Grindelwald has one of the most dramatic settings in Europe, gazing up at the mighty north face of the Eiger and its surrounding peaks. It’s part of the Jungfrau Ski Region that encompasses two valleys and three resorts, with more than 200km of runs. articles.description: The avalanche danger level in many French resorts has dropped to Level 4, but there is still a 'high' risk. Resorts are now re-opening slopes after some resorts shut for skiing completely. UPDATED The post French Resorts Re-Open Ski Areas as Avalanche Danger Drops appeared first on PlanetSKI .
articles.content: Saturday 14th February Resorts have now started re-opening slopes after avalanche mitigation work is carried out. The risk has dropped from Level 5 (Very High) to Level 4 (High). The authorities are advising against off piste skiing while urging people to stay to the marked and prepared runs. On Friday two Britons and a Frenchman died off piste in an avalanche in Val d’Isere: Two Britons amoung three dead in Val D’Isere avalanche It is expected there will be further fatalities over the next few days as more people venture off piste once the conditions start to stabilise. Level 3 (considerable) is the level where most accidents occur. The authorities are advising extreme caution as more areas open. articles.content: TL;DR – Read This First The 2025–26 winter season has seen unusually unstable snowpacks across both the Alps and North America. Despite repeated avalanche warnings from ski patrols, mountain guides and rescue services, many skiers and snowboarders continue to go off-piste during high-risk periods — sometimes ignoring advice, challenging warnings, or reacting aggressively when asked to turn back. When accidents happen, the same professionals who tried to prevent these decisions are forced to carry out complex and dangerous rescue operations , often in extremely unstable terrain. Respecting avalanche bulletins and closures doesn’t just protect skiers — it protects the rescuers who put their lives at risk to save others. Photo: Herbert Maeder. Wikipedia Commons. articles.content: Val Thorens winter driving rules have been tightened in the Belleville Valley, covering Val Thorens, Les Menuires and Saint-Martin-de-Belleville. These Val Thorens winter driving measures apply throughout the entire ski season. A new municipal decree confirms that vehicles must be equipped with either four winter tyres in good condition or snow chains . Snow socks and all-season tyres are explicitly not considered adequate equipment. For a full breakdown of winter tyre and snow chain rules across the Alps and Europe — including what’s accepted where and why — see our guide to winter tyres and snow chains . These Val Thorens winter driving rules are enforced throughout the Belleville Valley ski season. Under Article 4.2 of the decree, law enforcement may deny access to the resorts if vehicles are fitted with snow socks that are not suitable for heavily snow-covered or icy roads.
